ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Engaged in higher-level conversation and writing; became comfortable with the use of the language on multiple levels
This semester, I furthered my knowledge of Spanish vocabulary, tenses, grammar, history, and proficiency in speech.
I developed my speaking, reading, writing, and listening skills in Spanish.

My spanish has improved so much after this semester! Practicing spanish everyday was a bit tedious at times, but I am so much better off for it. My speaking, writing, and reading all significantly improved, as well as my understanding of Latin American culture after the readings and final projects.

You learn to be very proficient in Spanish in ALL basic types: speaking, listening, writing, reading. Definitely less of a focus on vocabulary, however, in the way that they teach it, you gain a lot along the way.
I read my first book in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would have liked a little more variance in the structure of our class days - some days devoted to open discussion and conversation as well as some days devoted to intensive grammar/writing work

The diversity of the format of each class was refreshing and engaging. In addition, you could tell how much the professor cared for her students and wanted them to succeed. Her passion and energy made the class fun to attend. I also enjoyed the time duration of class--I thought this was a great amount of time--and how classes were asynchronous on Fridays. The course could have been improved by making what was expected for homework more clear.
Very interactive and you learn a lot, but can be intense.

I thought this class was good overall, but the grading in it I think is rather harsh. Homework being graded for accuracy the day after you learn a verb tense or grammar structure can be tough. Or if you grade it for accuracy take less off for each mistake because making the same mistake throughout can take off a lot of points from your final grade even though your understanding isn't that far off.

Strengths: I really liked how we engaged with a lot of different media short films, poems, short stories. 
Weaknesses: I wish Profesora Alexandrov had expressed more clearly how important the cultural project would be to the course. I feel that my group mates and I did not realize how much time this project would take.

Strengths: Always engaged, very little busy work, feel like you're getting better every day, definitely feel confident in Spanish by the end.
Weaknesses: The homework is a little all over the place in terms of difficulty (Supersite is always a nice intro to topics but the Canvas HWs were pretty hard).
I really did not like the way we were tested and forced to incorporate certain words into a paragraph/sentence. I cant do that in English, let alone Spanish.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I think it is very beneficial in the process of furthering one's proficiency in the language.
Yes, if you want to improve your Spanish.
It's a tough class but I think I would recommend this course. It's rewarding to learn the material and it was a fun way to socialize with other students.
Yes if they want to fulfill the language credit or if they need to complete it for study abroad. This course is very much like a high school course, but it's definitely worthwhile.
